items.title: Unable to do migrations for a fresh installation
items.body:
## Describe the problem

Similar to #227 and #229 I have problems with my app migrations after implementing django-constance to [DFIRTrack](https://github.com/stuhli/dfirtrack). None of the solutions described there worked so far.

Everything went fine during development (existing application, installation of django-constance in addition to the existing application and adding configurations afterwards). But with a fresh installation (e. g. with Ansible, Github workflows) the migration fails.

BTW: Is the order of `INSTALLED_APPS` within `settings.py` okay?

## Steps to reproduce

A full stack track can be found within [DFIRTrack's Github workflows](https://github.com/stuhli/dfirtrack/runs/954636873?check_suite_focus=true).

I installed django-constance the "normal" way using pip.

### Reproducing the error

To reproduce the error a normal installation to the develop branch of DFIRTrack is sufficient:

* `git clone https://github.com/stuhli/dfirtrack.git dfirtrack`
* `cd dfirtrack`
* `virtualenv -p /usr/bin/python3 venv`
* `source venv/bin/activate`
* `git checkout develop`
* `pip install -r requirements.txt`
* `python3 manage.py migrate`

### Avoiding the error

In order to avoid the error first a migration to a "non-django-constance-state" is necessary and switching to a "django-constance-state" afterwards, e. g.:

* `git clone https://github.com/stuhli/dfirtrack.git dfirtrack`
* `cd dfirtrack`
* `virtualenv -p /usr/bin/python3 venv`
* `source venv/bin/activate`
* `git checkout dbda07828b6afbb1e189177c5bc5608c1a80bb14` ("non-django-constance-state" from a parallel branch)
* `pip install -r requirements.txt`
* `python3 manage.py migrate`
* `git checkout develop`
* `pip install -r requirements.txt` (for installing django-constance)
* `python3 manage.py migrate`

## System configuration

* Development system: Ubuntu 18.04
* Django version: 2.2.13
* Python version: 3.69
* Django-Constance version: 2.7.0
* django-picklefield: 3.0.1

Thanks in advance for your help!

items.title: django-picklefield update breaks backwards incompatibility on version 2.5
items.body:
### Describe the problem

Recent 3.0 patch to django-picklefield has caused a backwards compatibility error on django 1.11 when using django-constance 2.5. I can see that setup.py does not have this dependency versioned.

I added a manual requirement of django-picklefield==2.1.1 and this resolved our issues. 

### Steps to reproduce

Install django==1.11, django-constance==2.5[database] and use it. 

### System configuration

* Django version: 1.11
* Python version: 3.6
* Django-Constance version: 2.5[database]

items.title: Reset to default does not work with ImageField
items.body:
### Describe the problem

I tried the example with ImageField. Default value works. Uploading a new image also works. But if I click the link `Reset to default` nothing happen.

Reseting to default image is not possible.

### Steps to reproduce

Just use the example: 
https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/blob/2.6.0/docs/index.rst

```python
CONSTANCE_ADDITIONAL_FIELDS = {
    'image_field': ['django.forms.ImageField', {}]
}

CONSTANCE_CONFIG = {
    'LOGO_IMAGE': ('default.png', 'Company logo', 'image_field'),
}
```

### Tested with browser

Firefox and Chrome current stable. Same result with both.

### Possible source of the issue

Seems to be an issue with a javascript. Browsers show a error message in the console:

Firefox:
```
InvalidStateError: An attempt was made to use an object that is not, or is no longer, usable
```

Chrome:
```
jquery.js:8496 Uncaught DOMException: Failed to set the 'value' property on 'HTMLInputElement': This input element accepts a filename, which may only be programmatically set to the empty string.
```

Source of the issue seems `constance.js` line 23.


### System configuration

* Django version: 3.0.7
* Python version: 3.8.2
* django-constance version: 2.6


Thanks for your great library!

items.title: No wheel for 2.6.0
django.db.utils.IntegrityError after 2.5.0 release
items.body:
In #329 `DatabaseBackend.set` was changed. And now I have `IntegrityError` in my project.

The bottom line is that when doing parallel requests, the following happens:
On execute 
https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/blob/50287a3b2a3096ea89f6c28ba11935949fe21a27/constance/backends/database/__init__.py#L87
raised `self._model.DoesNotExist`
Then executed
https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/blob/50287a3b2a3096ea89f6c28ba11935949fe21a27/constance/backends/database/__init__.py#L93
raises `django.db.utils.IntegrityError` due to the fact that another thread was able to set the value earlier.

I cannot provide a test that will demonstrate this error.
I call here PR author @xuhcc, merger @camilonova and @jezdez as an observer.

items.title: Conflict with django-admin-interface
items.body:
### Description of the problem
Constance is replacing the classes applied by other apps in the block `bodyclass` of `admin/base_site.html`.

This generates a conflict for example with `django-admin-interface` because this app add some specific CSS class names in the body to change completely the style of the admin panel.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a django project with `constance` and `django-admin-interface`.
The repository and the instructions for the installation of `django-admin-interface` is here: 
```
    https://github.com/fabiocaccamo/django-admin-interface
```
2. Enter the admin panel of django
3. Enter to django-constance admin panel
4. All the style has been lost in that panel. That problem doesn't happen in the admin panel of other models. 

### Solution
To change `admin/constance/change_list.html` adding `{{ block.super }}` in the the block `bodyclass`, like this:
```
   {% block bodyclass %}{{ block.super }} change-list{% endblock %}
```

items.title: Ordered Fields
items.body:
**django-constance** does not store ordering of `CONFIG_FIELDSETS` without using OrderedDict

As of Python 3.6, for the CPython implementation of Python, dictionaries remember the order of items inserted. For 3.7+ that is rule. https://stackoverflow.com/a/39980744/5628843
That is happening due to [code](https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/blob/master/constance/admin.py#L273):
```python
            if not isinstance(settings.CONFIG_FIELDSETS, OrderedDict):
                context['fieldsets'].sort(key=itemgetter('title'))

        if not isinstance(settings.CONFIG, OrderedDict):
            context['config_values'].sort(key=itemgetter('name'))
```

This code was written at a time when dictionaries had no guarantee of order.
In my opinion, this code should be brought up to date.

I see the following points:
1) For people who use OrderedDict, everything should work without any changes.
2) People whose python does not guarantee the insertion order should continue to receive the sorted version.
3) I'm not sure, but maybe we should save the opportunity for people using modern python to get a sorted version. There must be an option for this. Although in fact we can do without it.

My motivation is that a regular dict looks a lot simpler than an OrderedDict

* Django version: 2.2
* Python version: 3.6

cc: @jezdez @camilonova

items.title: Provide a 'setting_defaults' backend for testing
items.body:
### Describe the problem

I have an issue/request that is similar to #285. In production and integration testing I run a redis backend, but in an effort to minimize complexity when running unit tests I want to be able to minimize the additional services that are running, such as redis.

### Suggested improvement

My suggestion is to have some kind of 'defaults' backend, which will simply return the default values defined in the `CONSTANCE_CONFIG` structure, unless they are overridden with an `override_config` directive. items.title: Providing `raw` attr on signal
items.body:
Hi - in ref this: https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/issues/158#issuecomment-529401938

I haven't checked, but one way might be to override the standard django  post_save and add `old_value` and `new_value` as kwargs. That way, one could listen for post_save (or pre_save) but also have the convenience of seeing the change. 

For the moment my workaround has just been to use the post_save signal for the Constance model because I didn't actually need to check the old/new values, so the custom signal wasn't necessary.

items.title: Use `gettext` in CONSTANCE_CONFIG_FIELDSETS

I'd like to use fieldsets in the Constance section on the Django admin site and have localized titles for its. Below, I will give an example where I will show that a common Django approach (which is usage of the function `gettext`) is impossible.

Let's say we have the following configuration in our settings.py

```
from django.utils.translation import ugettext_lazy as _

...

CONSTANCE_CONFIG_FIELDSETS = {

        'BREAKFAST_DEFAULT_IMAGE',
        'LUNCH_DEFAULT_IMAGE',
        'DINNER_DEFAULT_IMAGE',
        'SNACK_DEFAULT_IMAGE',

}
```

    return self.__text_cast()

As `_('Meal Cards')` is a key of a dictionary, it should be hashed and the lazy function `ugettext_lazy` should be evaluated immediately.

Could you add a support of a tuple for `CONSTANCE_CONFIG_FIELDSETS`? Like this:

items.title: Idea: Interest in advanced example showing DRY front-end forms with settings from specific fieldset?
items.body:
For my own project I needed to create front-end Constance forms that displayed only the settings for specific fieldsets. In my particular project, my Constance settings are split among 4 different fieldsets, and I wanted to display these settings separately in forms on tabs in a view. Each tab displays a form with only the settings for a specific formset, and each form can be submitted separately from the others. Similarly, I could add a view with just the content from one fieldset, multiple fieldsets, or all the fields, utilizing the same Form class.

The idea is similar to [Issue 273](https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/issues/273) by @gustavi but was created independent of his work, and focuses on using Constance's built-in fieldsets, rather than declaring individual fields, in order to simplify and make things DRY.

Would there be interest in a pull request that demonstrates all of this functionality? If there is, I'll be happy to extract the relevant content from my project.

If there is interest, should I add this as a separate example project, or overwrite the existing example project?

items.title: Unable to change values in admin panel even with permissions
Proposal : Add a way to create forms with only some fields
items.body:
Today we can only create a form with all settings fields.

**Proposal** : add a `fields` parameter in `constance.admin.ConstanceForm`. It would works like `CreateView` or `UpdateView` (https://github.com/django/django/blob/2.0/django/views/generic/edit.py#L72)

**Details** : 

- Move `ConstanceForm` to a `forms.py`.
- Add a `fields` parameter. Maybe `fields = '__all__'` by default, I dont know if it's relevant.
- Supports something like : 

```python
class MySettingsForm(ConstanceForm):
    fields = ('NAME', 'DESCRIPTION')

class LanguagesSettings(ConstanceForm):
    fields = ('LANGUAGE', 'RIGH_TO_LEFT')
```

I have a POC that's working but I want to discuss of the solution before.

https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/commit/bbc7db2edc6c70d62e2c795f9c454153d5efb86d#diff-8dc9a022cea95093a348d28ab2dd934d

https://github.com/jazzband/django-constance/blob/master/constance/admin.py#L255

items.title: Attempts to change config values fail silently and appear to succeed when user does not have change permissions
items.body:
### Describe the problem

Users with `is_superuser` set to `False` can view constance configs, but not edit them, by default. The constance admin interface UI shows no indication that the fields are readonly, or that the user does not have permission to edit them, and even makes it seem like the user has edited the field when they try to save changes.

This took a while to debug because it fails completely silently with no error message. As such I feel it could be friendlier.

Additionally, I'm not sure that letting non-superuser users view constance config values is a sensible default.

The issue in my case was solved by giving the staff user permissions, but this solution was found only on second reading of the documentation, as there's only a few lines that indicate anything about permissions in the docs, and no messaging in the admin interface indicates why attempts to change the constance configs failed.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Install constance
2. Access the admin interface as a user who a) is not a superuser, and b) does not have constance edit permissions.
3. View the constance config in the admin interface.
4. Attempt to edit the constance config (it will appear that the constance config has changed).
5. Go to a different area of the admin site and return to the constance configs.
6. At this point it will be apparent that the config has not changed.

### System configuration

* Django version: 1.8.18
* Python version: 2.7.14
* Django constance version: 2.1.0

items.title: Bad effects on python2 to python3 migration....
items.body:
### Describe the problem

This is probably a bit of a corner case, but I recently migrated a Django codebase from Python 2.7 to 3.6 and hit a problem with DateTime values stored in a constance database backed. The issue is that the pickled data was not unpickling properly and the underlying django-picklefield was returning the raw string object if the unpickle failed.

It seems that it is simply really hard to get a DateTime pickled in 2.7 to unpickle nicely in 3.6, but this is the sort of thing I can live with. The unfortunate bit is that constance doesn't seem to have a guard for picklefield returning the raw string and that crashes the Admin pages (it also crashed my app, but that's my problem!) - it probably shouldn't do that.... A better behaviour would be to put up a warning on the Admin pages to the effect that there is possible data corruption.

There is a work-around by using the constance command line interface to set the constants back to a valid datetime (it would be even nicer to have a 'reset' in the command interface to simple reset them to the default values) and the admin pages could be loaded again.

### Steps to reproduce

Setup constance to store some DateTime data whilst running a Python 2.7 codebase.
Upgrade to Python 3.x
Try to use the constance admin pages to look at the constance variables

### System configuration

* Django version: 1.11.1
* Python version: from 2.7.11 switching to 3.6.2

items.title: Missing info for 'version' field in docs for custom form
items.body:
The guide here fails to mention the need to include a "version" field in your custom form for it to work: https://django-constance.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html#custom-settings-form

An explanation on how to handle it properly would also be welcome.

```
class CustomForm(ConstanceForm):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super(CustomForm, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)

        self.helper = FormHelper()
        self.helper.layout = Layout(
            'FIELD1',
            'FIELD2',
            'version',  # Without this field, form will fail silently
        )
        self.helper.form_action = '.'
        self.helper.form_method = 'POST'
        self.helper.add_input(Submit('submit', 'Save'))
```

To reproduce simply make a custom form with all the fields defined in settings.py, it won't work. Add a 'version' field and it should work.

The invisible error can be seen in self.errors of CustomForm. (For example in clean()) 

### System configuration

* Django version: 1.10.7
* Python version: 3.5.2

items.title: Migration error for multiple databases: django.db.utils.ProgrammingError: (1146, "Table 'db_2.django_content_type' doesn't exist")
items.body:
### Describe the problem

Hi. We have a django site that uses 4 databases. I'm trying to install Constance on our Django site and am getting an error regarding the django_content_type table in one of the non-default databases. 

We've written a DB router to route selected apps to specific databases. Non-specified apps route to default. Because Django, we have a script to run the migrations for all the databases. 

```
python manage.py migrate --noinput 
python manage.py migrate --noinput --database=db_2 
python manage.py migrate --noinput --database=db_3 
python manage.py migrate --noinput --database=db_4 
```

Running the script gives the following error when it runs the db_2 command:

```  
Creating tables...
    Running deferred SQL...
  Installing custom SQL...
Running migrations:
  Rendering model states... DONE
  Applying database.0001_initial... OK
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "manage.py", line 10, in <module>
    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
  File "/Users/sholleman/src/.virtualenvs/sma/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 354, in execute_from_command_line

[...]

Migration error: django.db.utils.ProgrammingError: (1146, "Table 'db_2_staging.django_content_type' doesn't exist")
```

We considered creating a  `django_content_type` tables each database, but that feels wrong. Removing the two instances of `.using(using)` from create_perm() in apps.py stops the error, but breaks one of your tests, `test_post_migrate_signal_creates_content_type_and_permission_in_secondary_database`. I think the error is due to a disconnect between the migration and the post-migrate signal. The migration looks to our custom db router and doesn't do anything to db_2. But the create_perm() in apps.py is ignoring our db router. Do you have any suggestions for fixing this? 

### Steps to reproduce

- Have a multi-database site with a special DB mapping router to route model calls to the correct database. Only the default database has the table, `django_content_type`.
- Install Constance with database backend. 
- Run migrations for non-default database. e.g., `python manage.py migrate --noinput --database=ib_files`
- Error

### System configuration

* Django version: 1.8.15
* Python version: 2.7.12
